DOC.TEXT: East German Communists and opposition factions today resumed talks on the nation's future over the din of hundreds of protesters who banged on windows and demanded a part in the negotiations. The forum brought together various political parties, social organizations and fledgling pro-democracy movements into a council of more than 40 that is to advise the interim government until free elections in May. After two hours of debate, participants decided to allow five more groups, including the official trade union federation, to take part in the talks and granted observer status to four more. The negotiators agreed to meet each Monday to propose legislation and proposed that future discussions be carried live on television and radio. Hundreds of angry demonstrators disrupted the first hour of the session, using bullhorns to shout their demands to be included and banging on windows of the ground-floor conference room of the Lutheran Church building where the talks were held. ``Anyone who tries to force his participation in this way is not acting in the interests of democracy,'' President Manfred Gerlach said as the noise overwhelmed speakers. The participants proposed a message of solidarity to Premier Hans Modrow and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who meet Tuesday in Dresden. They said the German-German summit expresses the will of both nations to improve relations, but they warned against any moves that would damage the sovereignty of either state _ a call to leave the reunification issue off the agenda. The meeting comes a day after the Communist Party concluded an emergency congress in which it embraced a multiparty system and changed its name to the Socialist Unity Party of Germany-Party of Democratic Socialism. The long title reflects both a new orientation to democratic principles and an eagerness to divorce itself from the corruption and power abuses that tainted former Communist leaders ousted in a pro-democracy movement that began in September. New Communist Party leader Gregor Gysi and Wolfgang Berghofer, his chief deputy, opened the talks Dec. 7. At that session, May 6 was set as the date for the first-ever competitive elections to seat a new Parliament, kicking off a volatile campaign season likely to result in a minority role for the Communists. The talks have spurred the discredited Communists to consult with their broadening opposition on how to run the country until elections are held. In his address Sunday to the congress' final session, Gysi set out a new course for the party that breaks with four decades of Stalinism. Nearly 2,700 delegates unanimously approved the draft of a new statute, to serve as the party rulebook until its next regular congress, as well as the outlines of a new program. The Communists were stripped of their constitutional mandate to rule during a parliamentary session Dec. 1. It reduced their status to that of any other political force, though the premier and much of his Cabinet are Communist. When a new Parliament is seated after elections, it in turn will name a new government. The Communists polled only 12 percent support in a public opinion survey conducted by major West German pollsters in early December, and Modrow himself has predicted his party could win no more than 20 percent of the vote if elections were held now. Two other political conventions were held over the weekend, by the small Christian Democratic Union of East Germany that is aiming to win votes from the religious population, and by the opposition group Democratic Awakening. Despite the Communists' opposition to reunification, the theme has taken hold among some political groups. Delegates at the founding party congress of Democratic Awakening in Leipzig voted 350-35 with 21 abstentions that the right of German unity should be inscribed in the East German constitution. The Christian Democratic Union's leader, Lothar de Maiziere, told delegates he could envisage a single German state within a united Europe.
